ygData.subject: Re: [neat] differentiation
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Chad, ... In some circumstances, yes. If we take a problem that requires a network with color inputs as an example, we might not find a good solution if the

Hi Chad,

Chad Bohannan wrote:

> so let me try to summarize what you said.
> If I find a network that achieves some minimum fitness, adding new 
> nodes and continuing the search would be the best way to minimize the 
> search time.

In some circumstances, yes. If we take a problem that requires a network 
with color inputs as an example, we might not find a good solution if 
the problem is too complex, in this case one technique that can be 
employed is to search for solutions to a simpler problem that is 
closesly related to the problem we are trying to solve, say, recognising 
objects in monochrome instead of in color . The resulting network can 
then be used as a seed or starting point for the more complex (color) 
problem search.

> I want to find a color network in a comparable amount of time to a 
> monochrome network.

But a color signal by its very nature conveys more information than a 
monochromatic one, therefore any network that has to process this 
information would need to be more complex and will therefore require (on 
average) longer search times.

> Are there ways of using previously discovered topologies to speed up 
> searches?


See above. As an example take a look at one of Ken's recent papers 
(co-authored) "Evolving a Roving Eye for Go ", where networks are 
evolved to play Go, firstly on a 5x5 board and then on a 7x7 board.
http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=145

Another example would be: "Incremental Evolution Of Complex General 
Behavior"
http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=35


> Something that comes to mind from colins advice is to have stratified 
> features, and when one stratus of inputs reaches an acceptable 
> fitness, freeze evolution on those elements, and force the new stratus 
> of features to evolve around the previous features. This would keep 
> the dimensionality the same, and assuming that each stratus was of 
> comparable size, the search time would only increase linearly to the 
> number of additional inputs.

Ah I see, interesting idea. So long as the new problem with an increased 
number of inputs is an extension from the original problem rather than a 
modification then such a technique probably would be faster, since it 
avoids searching the network structure and weights that already do a 
perfectly good job. On the other hand the existing structure may have 
spare functional capacity that can handle the new problem by adjusting 
weights and modifying connections, in which case searching the existing 
structure may result in a smaller network overall.

Colin
